posts.text:
So if hill (H) valley (V) is a clock pulse, this procedure changes the signal from 
HVHVHVHVHVHV to 
HVVHHVVHHVVH

which decomposes to an octave above plus an octave below the original frequency. Next step is noticing that the rectified signal (HVHV -> HHHH) gives you an octave above.

reply_context.text: There's a way you can construct this that doesn't look the same as if you do it analytically, but which I think imparts a really strong intuition for what's going on. Treat the sine wave as a clock signal that flips an inverter on/off at each clock pulse.
